references.A08MUL01USGP: Mulcahy, D.G. 2008. Phylogeography and species boundaries of the western North American Nightsnake (Hypsiglena torquata): Revisiting the subspecies concept. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution 46:1095-1115.
references.B03STE01USGP: Stebbins, R.C. 2003. A field guide to western reptiles and amphibians.  Third Edition. Houghton Mifflin, Boston.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.

habitat_description:
The coast night snake is restricted to the coastal areas extending from northern California to southern Baja California (Mulcahy 2008). The region is characterized by bare rock, talus, scree, desert, grassland, savanna, herbaceous, chaparral, shrubland, and various woodland communities. This species burrows in or using soil, debris, decaying logs, and leaf litter. Long periods of inactivity are spent underground, or under rocks and crevices.

Habitats of preference include arid and semiarid plains, hillsides, canyons, deserts, grassland, shrubland, woodland, and savanna. In general, this species is found in rocky, hilly terrain with sandy or gravelly soils (Stebbins 2003).

SW	 - Cover is provided by rocks, crevices, soil, leaf litter, and other forms of decaying vegetation.

From Crothers et al 2012 regarding H torquata (modeled by ReGAP efforts) and 3 modeled species "The nominal species H. torquata is now restricted to Mexico, three described forms occur in the USA, and the undescribed form is endemic to the Cochise Filter Barrier area of southeastern Arizona and associated New Mexico"
